newsitem.title: CANADA: Canadian bonds open weaker in wake of poor auction.
newsitem.headline: Canadian bonds open weaker in wake of poor auction.

text.p: Canadian bonds opened weaker on Thursday as the impact of Wednesday's poorly received auction of 10-year Government of Canada bonds continued to weigh on prices, analysts said.
"We were much lower when we opened up. There's still a bad taste left from yesterday's auction," said Harvinder Kalirai, Canadian analyst with financial analysis firm I.D.E.A.

Canada's 30-year benchmark bond fell C$0.15 to C$109.65 to yield 7.176 percent. The U.S. 30-year bond rose 2/32 to yield 6.96 percent. The spread between the two bonds widened to 22 basis points from 19 basis points at Wednesday's close.

Canadian bonds fell sharply on Wednesday after the Canadian government said its C$2.4 billion auction of 7.25 percent bonds due June 1, 2007 produced an average yield of 6.66 percent, with a low yield of 6.639 percent and high yield of 6.700 percent.
Dealers said the auction's tail, the difference between high and average yield, was the highest in recent memory and was an indication of poor demand.
Canadian bonds did pare some of their earlier losses this morning on renewed strength in U.S. Treasuries, analysts said.
"We've pared our losses and I think that really has to do with the fact that the Fed did a coupon pass so Treasuries sort of picked up and Canada has really followed suit," said Kalirai.
In other prices, Canada's 10-year benchmark bonds fell C$0.05 to C$102.45 to yield 6.648 percent. The U.S. bond fell 1/32 to yield 6.76 percent.
The negative spread between the bonds narrowed to 11 basis points from 12 basis points on Wednesday.
